name: Florence
fun_fact: Fun fact: Florence invented the Negroni cocktail, and still serves wine through ancient 17th-century 'wine windows' (buchette del vino) - tiny stone openings where Prosecco or Chianti is passed to you, just like during the plague!

hero_dishes.name: Bistecca alla Fiorentina
hero_dishes.description: Massive T-bone steak cut 5-6 cm thick from Chianina cattle raised in Tuscany, grilled over wood fire and served rare
hero_dishes.origin_story: Must be from Chianina cows (an ancient Tuscan breed with PGI protection) to be authentic. The first official document about it dates to the Accademia della Crusca in 1750. Cut 3-4 fingers high in the loin, cooked rare on the grill - no compromise!
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Buca Lapi (1800s wine cellar), I'Tuscani (local favorite where the guide eats), Trattoria Mario (via Rosina), Regina Bistecca (near the Duomo), La Giostra. WARNING: Many places use meat from Northern Europe or South America - true bistecca must be Tuscan Chianina!

hero_dishes.name: Hand-rolled Pasta
hero_dishes.description: Fresh pappardelle, tagliatelle, and other hand-rolled pastas with wild boar ragÃ¹ or other Tuscan sauces
hero_dishes.origin_story: Tuscany's tradition of hand-rolling pasta dates back centuries, with each shape perfectly suited to catch the region's hearty meat sauces
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional trattorias throughout Oltrarno neighborhood, paired with local Chianti Classico wine

hero_dishes.name: Lampredotto
hero_dishes.description: Street food sandwich made from cow's fourth stomach, slow-cooked in tomato broth with vegetables
hero_dishes.origin_story: Historic Florentine working-class dish, now a beloved street food served from traditional green carts throughout the city
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors near Mercato Centrale and throughout the historic center

signature_drinks.name: Negroni
signature_drinks.description: Equal parts gin, Campari, and sweet vermouth, garnished with orange peel
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Invented in Florence! Enjoy as aperitivo before dinner at historic cafÃ©s. Order it with confidence - this is its birthplace!

signature_drinks.name: Chianti Classico DOCG
signature_drinks.description: Bold red wine from Sangiovese grapes, instantly recognizable by its 'Gallo Nero' (Black Rooster) emblem used since 1924
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Perfect pairing with bistecca fiorentina and wild boar ragÃ¹. The Chiantigiana road (SR 222) from Florence to Siena passes through acre upon acre of these famous vineyards. Best visited during September harvest when grapes ripen on the vines.

signature_drinks.name: Vin Santo
signature_drinks.description: Sweet dessert wine traditionally served with cantucci (almond biscotti) for dipping
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The traditional end to a Tuscan meal - dip the hard biscotti into the sweet wine

food_culture_notes: Wine served through historic 17th-century wine windows (buchette del vino) in Oltrarno - a rare experience where drinks are passed through stone openings
Oltrarno neighborhood (across Ponte Vecchio) is where locals eat - avoid the tourist traps near the Duomo
Florence has a local statute requiring restaurants source at least 70% of ingredients from Tuscany
Aperitivo culture is strong - enjoy a Negroni with small bites before dinner
The region produces not just Chianti but also cold cuts from pork, wild boar, and the famous 'cinta senese' pig

landmarks: Ponte Vecchio bridge lined with jewelry shops
atmosphere: Wine windows in ancient stone walls
unique_modern: Green street food carts selling lampredotto
